title: 111_s685
content:
The Act titled "Oil Spill Prevention Act of 2010" includes provisions for oil fuel tank protection. Section 3306 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to require vessels constructed or delivered after certain dates with a capacity of 600 cubic meters or more of oil fuel to comply with oil fuel tank protection regulations. The Secretary may also apply these regulations to vessels not subject to the convention. MARITIME EMERGENCY PREVENTION: Vessels with a capacity of 600 cubic meters or more of oil fuel must comply with oil fuel tank protection regulations. The Secretary has the authority to apply these regulations to vessels not covered by the convention. The Ports and Waterways Safety Act of 1972 is amended to include direction to change vessel heading and speed in emergencies. The Secretary of the department operating the Coast Guard must provide guidance on directing vessel movement for safety and require vessel identification in traffic service areas. The Secretary of the department operating the Coast Guard conducts safety assessments to prioritize ports and waterways needing vessel traffic management improvements based on traffic volume, collision risks, and projected impacts. The Secretary conducts safety assessments to prioritize ports and waterways needing vessel traffic management improvements based on traffic volume, collision risks, and projected impacts. The Secretary identifies requirements for necessary expansion, improvement, or construction of infrastructure to enhance existing vessel traffic service systems or support new systems. Personnel recruitment, retention, training, and workforce expansion are also reviewed and validated. The Secretary prioritizes ports and waterways for vessel traffic management improvements based on safety assessments. This includes expanding workforce to maintain effectiveness and providing basic navigation training for watchstander personnel to monitor vessel movements and provide advisories. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of enacting the Act, consolidating analysis results and recommendations for implementing study findings, including advisories for vessel masters. SEC. 4. The Coast Guard must have trained pollution investigators available at all times for each Sector Command. SEC. 5. Credentials have a specified duration. The Merchant Mariner's Documents and Licenses are valid for a 5-year period and can be renewed for additional 5-year periods. Renewals can be done up to 8 months in advance but only become effective after the previous document expires. The Merchant Mariner's Documents and Licenses are valid for a 5-year period and can be renewed for additional 5-year periods. Renewals can be done up to 8 months in advance but only become effective after the previous document expires. Additionally, certificates of registry for medical doctors or professional nurses also follow a similar renewal process. Possession of a medical doctor or registered nurse license issued by a State allows for renewal up to 8 months in advance, becoming effective after the previous certificate expires. SEC. 6. Authorization to extend the duration of licenses, certificates, and merchant mariners' documents. Chapter 75 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to allow the Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard operates to extend expiring licenses or certificates of registry for up to one year under certain circumstances. This extension may be necessary to address backlogs in processing applications, due to records being destroyed or unavailable because of a natural disaster, or to align expiration dates. The Secretary may extend expiring merchant mariner documents for up to one year under specific circumstances, such as addressing processing backlogs, records being unavailable due to a natural disaster, or aligning expiration dates with transportation worker identification credentials. The transportation worker identification credential can be extended for individual seamen or a group, with the authority expiring on December 31, 2011. A clerical amendment is made to the chapter analysis. SEC. 7. ELIMINATION OF CERTAIN REPORTS.

    The Coast Guard will now submit only one report per year on port security terrorism exercises, starting from October 2010, as directed by the House of Representatives Committee on Appropriations.

SEC. 8. BUDGETARY EFFECTS SEC. 8. BUDGETARY EFFECTS

The budgetary effects of this Act will be determined by the latest statement submitted by the Chairman of the Senate Budget Committee before the vote on passage.
